Title: The Formal Turn - The Emergence of Formalism in Twentieth-Century Thought

This interdisciplinary project seeks to investigate the emergence of formalism in twentieth-century thought, with a focus on the philosophy of science and logic. The project's objective is to conduct a comprehensive and comparative study of the early contributions to formalism, spanning the late nineteenth century to the mid-twentieth century.

The project is divided into three subprojects. The first subproject, "Historical Reconstruction," will explore the roots of formalism in nineteenth-century mathematics and Neo-Kantian epistemology, with a focus on key figures such as Hermann Cohen, Ernst Cassirer, and Paul Natorp. The second subproject, "Comparative Study," will examine the formal turn in logic and its relation to logical empiricism, highlighting the work of David Hilbert, Paul Bernays, Gerhard Gentzen, Rudolf Carnap, and Moritz Schlick. The third subproject, "Analysis of Philosophical Implications," will delve into the philosophical consequences of formalism, including semantics in logic and philosophy, philosophy of model theory, inferentialism, and the logical study of scientific theories.

By adopting an interdisciplinary approach, this project aims to provide a nuanced understanding of the complex historical and conceptual developments that shaped the emergence of formalism in the early twentieth century. The project's outcomes will contribute significantly to the philosophy of science and logic, shedding new light on the intellectual foundations of modern formalism and its ongoing impact on various fields of inquiry.
